TI: 40Ar39Ar dating of highpressure rocks in the tananao basement complex Taiwan
AB: The appearance of the glaucophane schists and the omphacite-bearing rocks in the Yuli Belt of the Tananao Basement Complex indicates that a high-pressure metamorphic event occurred in Taiwan. The precise message of these high-pressure metamorphic rocks on the regional tectonic evolution history, however, is not yet clear mainly because of the complicated thermal history and the rarity of reliable geochronological data. To delineate the geohistory of these rocks, amphibole, phengite, phlogopite and omphacite separated from one glaucophane schist and two omphacite-bearing rocks were analyzed by using the 40Ar/39Ar dating technique. Omphacite and phlogopite separated from the omphacite-bearing rocks yield 40Ar/39Ar dates of 100-110 Ma and 4.4±0.1 Ma, respectively. Two phengite fractions of different grain size extracted from the glaucophane schist sample exhibit flat age spectra with consistent plateau dates of 10.4±0.1 Ma and 11.3±01 Ma. However, the age spectrum of amphibole from the glaucophane schist displays a disturbed shape with a geologically meaningless total gas age of 20.1±0.2 Ma. Such a disturbed isotopic system may be interpreted as resulting from mixing of two radiogenic Ar components which exhibit 40Ar/39Ar dates of ∼110 Ma and 12.2 Ma, respectively. Based on these results, three major conclusions could be made: (1) the high-pressure metamorphic event in Taiwan, as disclosed by the 40Ar/ 39Ar dates of omphacite and amphibole took place during 110-100 Ma; (2) the K-Ar isotopic systems of most of the minerals in these high-pressure rocks have been significantly affected by the thermal event of the late Tertiary Penglai Orogeny; and (3) the thermal event of the Penglai Orogeny may have occurred since as early as ca. 11 Ma ago.

TI: A study on hokutolite synthesis and its mineralogical implications to natural occurrences
AB: Synthetic hokutolite samples with chemical compositions different from natural crystals were grown in the present study with the solutions of Pb(NO3)2, Ba(NO3)2 and (NH4)2SO4 as starting materials. All the growth processes were carried out at 90-98°C and ambient pressure conditions for the growth period of 3-4 days. The synthetic hokutolite samples exhibit a well-developed crystal form with only a few crystals showing extensive surface defects. The present study reveals that hokutolite crystals can be grown with compositions covering the whole solid solution series of PbSO4 and BaSO4, unlike the limited PbSO4 content (21 to 32 mol%) observed in natural specimens. A variation in the growth rate of the synthetic hokutolite as a function of chemical composition was observed. X-ray measurements indicate that both the ao and bo crystallographic axes decrease with increasing PbSO4, while the co axis does not display the significant variation throughout the entire solid solution range. The inferior crystallinity of the synthetic hokutolite crystals may be closely related to the existence of the domain substructures in the samples. This work also suggests that the chemical compositions of natural hokutolite in the Peito area may have been controlled by the hot spring source materials which originated from the post-volcanic activity of Pleistocene volcanoes.

TI: Channel morphology on the eastern slope of the Coastal Range in Taiwan
AB: The Coastal Range is the most active tectonic area in Taiwan. Subject to continual stress coming from the southeast, the Coastal Range has been deformed by several faults and folds. Besides, uplift has led to the emergence of marine terraces in the coastal area. Due to the heterogeneous resistance of rock, various geological structure and differential uplift, most rivers have a straight course with gorge and intrenched valley in the steep slopeland, but ingrown meanders and intrenched meanders in the gentle slopeland and basin areas. In the alluvial fan and coastal area, channels are marked by straight course or meander depending on the slope. Responding to the baselevel lowering, a river adjusts by changing channel form depending on the magnitude and rate of baselevel change, valley slope and magnitude. It is concluded that the channel morphology is controlled by the resistance of rock, terrain topography, geological structure and tectonic movement.

TI: Crustal structures estimated from arrival differences of the first Pwaves in Taiwan
AB: A statistical relation between epicentral distance (X) and observed apparent velocity (V) has been constructed to estimate the average crustal P-wave velocity structures in the Taiwan area. The relation was derived from 17,502 apparent velocities of the first P-waves that were generated by 1,111 local shallow earthquakes and recorded at a regional telemeter seismic network (CWBSN) in Taiwan during the period from March 1991 to October 1994. Each apparent velocity was simply determined from the arrival difference between two close stations. Apparent velocities were obtained at various epicentral distances ranging from 50 to 300 km. To estimate velocity structures, the statistical relation of (X, V) was compared with the theoretical results calculated from assumed multi-layer models. The best P-wave velocity model to fit the statistical relation of (X, V) suggests that the maximum crust thickness probably reaches up to about 50 km, and that the upper crust has about double the thickness of the lower crust in the major part of Taiwan.

TI: Gravel orientation and their shapes distribution appear to effect slope grade in northwestern Taiwan
AB: The orientation of lateritic gravels and their slope distribution in northwestern Taiwan appear to effect slope stability. The results of in-situ investigation demonstrate that a scarp slope will be found when the intersected angle of strike on the gravel orientation and slope surface is 180°. By contrast, when the intersected angle is 0°, there is a dip slope geometry. When the intersected angle ranges from 0° to 180°, the slope grade will increase and have an angle of from 50° to 80°. The results indicate a positive correlation between the two. When the disk and bladed gravels increase their percentage relative to the material composition, the slope grade will increase. On the other hand, when the proportion of equant and roller shapes increase in the composition, the slope grade will decrease. The results of the study areas demonstrate that the gravel shape and its orientation still effect slope grade even when the matrix strength is constant. When the fine fraction content is over 30% in the matrix support of lateritc gravels, gravel shapes and their orientation can still effect the stability of such a slope.

TI: Gravimetric examination of thinskinned detachment vs basementinvolved models for the Taiwan Orogen
AB: Newly available gravity data are used to test two thin-skinned models and a recently proposed basement-involved model for the Taiwan Orogen, with the latter model requiring the discrete incorporation of autochthonous basement material into the shallow parts of the orogen. A comparison between the calculated and observed gravity anomalies shows that the basement-involved model significantly surpasses the thin-skinned models in fitting the data. TI: Investigation of active faults by ground penetrating radar along highway 3 Omi northwestern Taiwan
AB: Great population density and rapid industrial development in Taiwan have given rise to ever increasing demands for land. In order to meet this need, newly developed community sites must be planned in advance; however, as Taiwan is located along the neotectonic belt surrounding the Pacific Ocean, active fault detection is one of the most essential tasks for the earthquake risk analysis of different sites. Detecting shallow faults is thus one of the most important responsibilities for site investigation. The objective of this study was to assess the potential application of ground penetrating radar (GPR) to detect active faults in northwestern Taiwan. Three sites along highway #3 near Fu-hsintai, O-mi, northwestern Taiwan were selected. Each site has its own characteristics. A roadcut underneath site #1 allowed interpretation of the GPR results with the maximum amount of geologic control. Site #2 is located on a slope, where/and a gravel layer is unconformably overlying on dipping layers of sandstone and clay alternations. Topographic corrections for the field GPR data had to be done before the data was processed. Site #3 is located in front of a steep outcrop consisting of alternations of sandstone and mudstone, a thrust fault with a maximum throw of 3 m cross-cutting the vertical surface of the outcrops. From studying the images of subsurface spatial stratigraphy from the characters of radar sections, fault zones can be recognized in those sites. Comparing the observed radar sections with the modeled radar results, these fault zones can be distinguished more definitely. The GPR technique clearly demonstrated its capability of resolving local fault problems.

TI: NTUG rock standards for geochemical analysis
AU: Yang T;Yang C;Lee C;Chung S;Chen C
AB: The USGS rock standards, used in geochemical laboratories worldwide since the seventies, have been consumed and are unavailable. Based on recent geochemical studies in Taiwan and adjacent regions, some igneous rocks, e.g., the "enriched" andesite in Lutao and the highly potassic basalt in Tsaolingshan, show a strongly enriched incompatible trace element composition far beyond that of common rock standards. It is therefore highly necessary to prepare new secondary rock standards suitable for geochemical analyses of rock samples from Taiwan and elsewhere. Six rock standards, termed as NTUG (National Taiwan University, Department of Geology) were selected in different localities, including (1) Penghu alkali basalt, (2) Wannienta olivine basalt, (3) Kuanyinshan two-pyroxene andesite, (4) Lutao pyroxene-hornblende andesite and (5) Chinmen biotite granite and (6) gneiss. Major and trace element compositions for these rocks have been carried out by INAA, ICP-AES, ICP-MS and XRF methods. Whereas their tentative recommended values are given in this paper, further studies in terms of other techniques and more interlaboratory calibrations are needed. The NTUG standards are available upon request.

TI: Numerical simulation of neotectonics near Peikang high
AB: Neotectonic deformation near the Peikang basement high induces a sequence of phenomena, such as the development of faults, the occurrence of earthquakes and the detainment of displacement of the Western Foothills near the boundary of the Peikang high. In this paper, the neotectonic deformation near the Peikang high was simulated using a finite element computer code, ABAQUS. Infinite elements, interface elements and a measure of failure possibility were adopted to provide improvements in modeling the interfaces of the geological strata, reducing the number of elements, providing adequate boundary conditions and evaluating the possibility of faulting. The simulated results were then compared to the existing phenomena including the occurrences of micro-earthquakes, configuration of faults and displacement field measured by the Global Positioning System (GPS). The simulated results indicate that the induced strain energy is greater in the southern region than in the northern region, which explains why there are more earthquakes in the southern region. The simulated displacement field agrees with GPS records and reveals the occurrence of right and left lateral faults. Based on the simulation of vertical plane deformation, the location of thrust faults would occur at the rear of the up-thrusting block, which is consistent with field observations. The frictional effect of interfaces between the two main geological units (the Peikang high and the Western Foothills) was also evaluated. The results indicate that the increase in friction disperses the strain energy to a larger region, and the best fit of the friction angle is estimated to be about 10 to 20 degrees. Furthermore, the effect of relative stiffness was studied.

TI: Possible links between the development of PlioPleistocene coral reef limestones and thrust migration in southwestern Taiwan
AU: Gong S;Lee T;Wu J;Wang S;Yang K
AB: The southwestern Taiwan is part of a Plio-Pleistocene foreland basin filled with thick siliciclastic sediments. Embedded in these sequences are several lenticular reef limestones which are characterized by: (1) a rapid transition from underlying deep-water siliciclastic mudstones upward to reef limestones, (2) a lateral interfingering with deep-water siliciclastics, (3) an overlay of terrestrial deposits or of no other strata, implying an emergence above sea level since the reef formation, and (4) a location closely associated with anticlines. The authors propose that the majority of the Pleistocene reef limestones in southwestern Taiwan, including the Tudikungchi, Takangshan, Hsiaokangshan, Panpingshan and Kaohsiung Limestones, were deposited on local structural highs formed by thrust-induced anticlinal ridges that resulted from the cratonward migration of the orogen. They also speculate that the overall age-spatial distributions of these reef limestones could possibly represent thrust-front migration of the foreland basin.

TI: Secondary compression behavior of the silty clay of the Taipei Basin
AB: The secondary compression of the soil could have a significant effect on the ground settlement and is often not accounted for. It is the objective of this research to study the secondary compression behavior of the silty clay of the Taipei Basin. The traditional one-dimensional consolidation tests were performed, and the secondary compression behavior was observed. The ratio of the secondary compression index to the compression index is approximately 0.0274 for the silty clay of the Taipei Basin. The model proposed by Mesri and the rheological model by Gibson and Lo were used for interpretation of the secondary compression testing results and were then applied in the analyses of a field case. It is found that the amount of settlement predicted using the Gibson and Lo model appears to be more consistent with the field condition. However, the rate of pore pressure dissipation is faster than the observed field condition.

TI: Sismic and morphological characteristics of the Kaohsiung submarine Canyon southwestern Taiwan
AB: The Kaohsiung Canyon, the smallest of the submarine canyons on the southwestern Taiwan margin, extends from the shelf edge along a straight course on the upper slope to the 700 m isobath. Multichannel seismic profiles reveal the seismic characteristics and infer the sedimentary processes forming the canyon. In the upper canyon, the seismic profiles reveal slumping features and the termination of parallel reflectors against the steep canyon walls, suggesting erosional canyon downcutting. In the lower canyon segments, seismic configurations illustrate relatively flat reflectors onlapping the canyon bottom, resulting from sediment infilling. Two types of canyon fills are recognized: a chaotic fill and a mounded onlap fill, both suggesting gravity mass transport. On the basis of seismic interpretations, this canyon can be divided into two parts: an upcanyon erosional zone and a downcanyon mixed depositional and erosional zone. The course of the Kaohsiung Canyon is remarkably short and straight but with no distributaries as compared to the adjacent long and sinuous Kaoping Canyon. The cross-sectional morphology changes from V-shaped in the upcanyon sections (erosional zone) to U-shaped in the downcanyon sections (depositional and erosional zone). The seismic data provide no evidence for a fault zone along the canyon course. Rather, downslope submarine excavation is the major process forming the canyon.

TI: Source parameters of the December 15 1993 Tapu earthquake from firstP motions and waveforms
AB: On December 15, 1993, an earthquake of ML=5.8 occurred in Tapu, 34 km south of Chia-i, Taiwan. This earthquake was the largest occurring in southern Taiwan in the past thirty years. The event was recorded by both the local short-period seismic network and the digital strong motion array of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB). A method was proposed to determine the source parameters using both data sets. On the basis of the epicenter as determined by the short-period seismic network, the source depth was estimated at 20 km by the S-P time, the time difference between S- and P-arrivals, using strong motion data. Not just the short-period but also strong motion first-P motion data were used to determine the source mechanism of this event. From the modeling of the three-component displacement waveforms based on the determined source mechanism, the moment and other source parameters were determined. The results from a constrained modeling of the near source waveform showed a thrust fault with a strike of 12°, a dip of 52°, a rake of 70°, a source time duration of 1.0 sec, a seismic moment of 2.4× 1024 dyne-cm and a stress drop of 320 bars. The method proposed in this study also proved itself successful in determining the source parameters of small events. With the same technique applied to the aftershock on January 3, 1994, well constrained source parameters were estimated with a strike of 12°, a dip of 65°, a rake of 5°, a source time duration of 0.6 sec, a moment of 2× 1023 dyne-cm and a stress drop of 124 bars. The maximum compression axes of both source mechanisms were consistent with the major earthquakes and the regional stress direction in this area.

TI: Study on the correlation between slope failure occurrence time and rainfall data A case study on ALiSan Highway
AB: This project attempts to correlate the relationship between slope failure occurrence time and rainfall data along the A-Li-San Highway of Taiwan. It is believed that the results of this study will help to establish a landslide warning system in the future. About ten years' worth of data on rainfall and slope failure obtained from weather stations near the highway and highway maintenance unit have been collected and analyzed. Field measurements were carried out to determine the geological and topographical data of the rock slopes both for failed and unfailed slopes. This study yields two important result. First, the SMR(slope mass rating) method can be used to classify the stability of natural rock slopes along the highway. Statistically, the higher the SMR values of the rock slopes, the larger amount of rainfall is required to fail them. The SMR values corrected with the height-steepness factor show even better result. The second important result of this study is that the occurrence rate of slope failure along A-Li-San Highway can be expressed by the following formula: Occurrence Rate (%) = 20.59 + 1.281 + 0.11P where I = the maximum 3-hour duration rainfall intensity of a rainstorm, in mm/hr; P = cumulative rainfall, in mm. Nevertheless the slope failure is only expected to occur when the cumulative rainfall is greater than 80 mm for a rainstorm.

TI: The crustal evolution of continental Taiwan
AU: Lan C;Chen C;Chen C;Chung S;Lee T;Lee C;Yui T
AB: Based on isotopic and geologic data published in the past decade, the crustal evolution of the western continental part of Taiwan is summarized. The data show that the middle Proterozoic era was the most important period in terms of crustal formation and that the continental crust thus formed became a major protolith incorporated in the generation of younger Taiwan rocks. The crustal history of continental Taiwan began in the late Paleozoic (250±20 Ma). Four episodes of mantle inputs since then can be delineated: (1) the early Mesozoic event (200-175 Ma) in the metapelites of the Tananao metamorphic basement complex; (2) the late Mesozoic event (97-77 Ma) in the granitoids of the Tananao metamorphic basement complex; (3) the Cenozoic event (37-8 Ma) in the intraplate basalts of the Western Foothills of Taiwan; and (4) the ongoing event (3 Ma to present) in the recent volcanics of northern Taiwan. The first event is believed to have been a consequence of early Yanshanian thermal activity, whereas the second event could have been affiliated with the subduction of a paleo-Pacific plate. The third event resulted from continental extension in the SE China Continental Margin. As a response to arc-continent collision, the last event may be attributed to the change from a compressive to a dilational tectonic regime in the northern Taiwan orogen during the late Tertiary to Quaternary, rather than related directly to the Ryukyu subduction zone magmatism as commonly suggested.

TI: The crystal structure of vesuvianites from Taiwan
AB: The crystal structure of two vesuvianites in rodingite from the Yu-Ii area, Taiwan, were determined from data collected on a Nonius CAD-4 four-circle diffractometer. Two samples are brown and green in color, respectively. The results indicate that the brown vesuvianites have high Ti content and that the increase in Ti is fairly well correlated with the decrease in Al. In contrast, the green ones are characterized by a very low Ti concentration. Very low fluorine and boron content in these two samples were also noted. The two samples belong to the space group of P4/nnc and have similar chemistry and cell parameters (a=15.547,15.508Å; c=11.833, 11.815Å. Full-matrix least squares refinement of the structure, including anisotropic temperature factors, gave conventional and weighted R values of 6.72, 3.61 and 6.60, 4.49 %, respectively for these two specimens. The structures are virtually identical, and very similar to that proposed by Coda et al. (1970). The refinement results show the position for the H atom at the distance of about 0.6 Å from O(11). According to the analysis of a difference Fourier synthesis, the bond-valence calculations and relationship between B-O(10) and O(10)-O(10) distance, it demonstrates that another H atom should bond to O(10). Cations in vesuvianites are mainly confined to the 6-fold AlFesites (Al, Fe, Mg, Ti) and 5-fold B-sites (Fe, Al, Mg). The 4-fold sites are filled with Si, the 8-fold sites with Ca (minor Na), and the 6-fold A-sites with Al. Furthermore, along the 4-fold axis of the structure, adjacent B-sites (tetrahedral pyramid) and C-sites (square antiprism) are half occupied because of the close cation-cation distance of about 1.4A.

TI: The investigation of landslides and stability analyses of slopes along the roads in the NanHwa Reservoir watershed area
AB: The Nan-Hwa Reservoir, located at Nan-Hwa, Tainan County, is well recognized as an important hydraulic construction in southwestern Taiwan. The reservoir area is selected as the major study area in this project due to the occurrence of disastrous landslides there. The watershed of the Nan-Hwa Reservoir is 108.29 square kilometers in size with thirty-six creeks. The major traffic routes in the reservoir area are Pin-Ken Road, Kun-Sen Road, County Road 179 and Provincial Highway 20. Along the major roads, a total of 43 landslides and 24 disposal fields of dumped soils, resulting from the construction of Road 179, are investigated. The fields of dumped soils, located at 10k+230m on Road 179, is selected to explore the mechanical characteristics and stability of these wasted materials after being disturbed by human activity in the mudstone areas. The research mainly contains field tests and laboratory experiments. The field tests include surveys on disposal fields of dumped soil, geological investigations, field soil density determinations and sieve analyses of soils. In laboratory, soil compaction tests, consolidation tests, direct shear tests, tri-axial tests, and basic determenations of soil mechanical characteristics are conducted. Compaction tests in this research are based on the ASTM D698-A and the AASHTO T99-A method. Slope stability analyses are performed by use of the computer program STABLE V. The results show that the disturbed mudstone works satisfactorily in slope stabilities between 90% and 95% relative compaction. This study evaluates the stabilization of the dumped soils and the natural landslides of mudstones in southwestern Taiwan.

TI: The salinization of groundwater in the northern LanYang Plain Taiwan Stable isotope evidence
AB: Saline groundwaters have been detected from the evidence provided by conductivity and chemistry in the northern coastal area of the Lan-Yang Plain, I-Lan county, Taiwan. The mechanisms of groundwater salinization were diagnosed by measurements of isotopic analyses in this study. Two main processes are identified as being responsible for the stable isotope enrichment in groundwaters: (1) the intrusion of sea water, and (2) the mixing of isotope-enriched surface water into the aquifer. The major reason for groundwater salinization has been sea water encroachment resulting from the overpumping of groundwater by farmers using freshwater aquaculture in this area. In order to alleviate groundwater salinization, measures and regulations with regard to safe drawing control for groundwaters should be strictly adopted and enforced in the coastal areas of Taiwan.

TI: δ13CPDB variations in contemporary bryophytes and the constraint on its use as a proxy of paleoatmospheric CO2 contents
AB: One potential proxy of the concentration records of the paleoatmospheric CO2 is the δ13C values of organic sediments. However, factors other than the δ13C values and concentration of the atmospheric CO2, such as ambient air humidity, are also important in controlling the δ13C values of terrestrial plants. In order to overcome the "humidity problem", fossil bryophyte samples were recently analyzed to reconstruct the concentration records. However, since the concentrations and the δ13C values of forest air CO2 are probably heterogeneous and different from those of the atmospheric CO2, δ13C values of bryophyte samples shall then reflect the records of the forest air rather than the atmospheric CO2. In this study, a suite of contemporary bryophyte samples were analyzed to test this hypothesis. The samples were collected from a small area of the forest in the Yuen-Yang Lake Natural Reserve Area. The δ13CPDB values of the samples analyzed in this study ranged from -26.1 to -30.77‰, with a spread of 4.6‰. Based on these δ13CPDB values, these bryophyte samples appear to be C3-plants. The 4.6‰ spread is for all the samples analyzed, which consisted of five different species of bryophytes. In terms of single species variation, the spread is 2.5‰. It can be argued that the spreads are a result of the isotopic heterogeneity of the forest air CO2 and that, in general, the forest air CO2 and the atmospheric CO2 are different in their δ13C values and concentration levels. This phenomenon had to be dealt with when the δ13C values of fossil bryophyte samples were used to reconstruct the concentration records of paleoatmospheric CO2. The seriousness of the phenomenon is fully appreciated in view of the fact that the full range of fluctuation of the δ13C values of the averaged atmospheric CO2 of the last one hundred and sixty thousand years is probably only within 2.0‰.

TI: A study of the effects of source scaling on seismic zonation in southwestern Taiwan
AB: The effects of seismic source scaling of the Tachienshan-Chukou fault system in southwestern Taiwan on seismic zonation are investigated in this study. To simplify the problem, this fault system is assumed to be the only seismic source in the area of interest. The attenuation of strong ground motions is modeled by the modififed specific barrier model developed for ground motion simulation in the near-source regime. Probabilistic seismic hazard analyses are evaluated for sites in the vicinity of the fault system. It has been found that the scaling relationship of corner frequency and seismic moment can be extended to that of fault rupture length and earthquake magnitude. The hazard assessments at sites close to the fault system are not very sensitive to the scaling relationship of the fault provided that the attenuation equation is kept invariant. The attenuation of ground motion is the major factor that affects the results of seismic hazard analyses. With respect to a return period of 475 yr, a peak ground acceleration of 0.8 g is a possible value for sites close to the Tachienshan-Chukou fault system.

TI: Alkane distributions and their geochemical significance in the TzaiKang core of the Coastal Plain southwestern Taiwan
AU: Oung J;Sung Q;Lin Y;Liu T;Yang C
AB: The Tzai-kang core from the southwestern Coastal Plain was analyzed by GC-MS for biomarkers including n-alkanes, triterpanes, and steranes. The alkane distributions indicate that hydrocarbons of various origins, such as reworked sedimentary rocks from the catchment area, biogenic terrestrial higher plants and, ocasionally, microbial algae/microbial, are present in the Coastal Plailn. The dominance of fossil hydrocarbons reflects the poor preservation of the biological organic matter and great dilution effects caused by a high sedimentary rate in the southwestern Coastal Plain. Organic origins and processes occurring during the transportation and after the deposition are recorded in the alkane distribution. Attempts have been made to correlate the n-alkane distribution with the depositional environment. It is shown that the n-alkane distributions reflect the non-marine environments by showing relatively higher amounts of terrestrial n-alkanes in the range of n-C27-n-C33 derived from terrestrial higher plants. On the other hand, the samples of the lagoonal environmental always show significantly higher amounts of low molecular weight n-alkanes ranging from n-C15 to n-C20 which are related to the algae/microbial origin. This correlation infers that n-alkane distributions in the Tzai-kang core might, to some extent, reflect the environmental changes indicated by foraminifera examination.

TI: Calcite twin analysis of the Tungho and Kangkou limestones in the Coastal Range eastern Taiwan
AB: The Tungho and Kangkou Limestones of the Coastal Range in eastern Taiwan have been deformed during the arc-continent collision since Pliocene. The stress and strain states of these deformed limestones are determined from the analysis of calcite twin lamellae. The present study shows that most limestones have suffered only a single phase of deformation under compressional stress. The derived maximum principal stress (σ1) is close to h orizontal and trends mainly in the range of 100° to 140° in azimuth. The directions of the σ2 and σ3 are either near horizontal or vertical and their magnitudes are nearly equal. Beside the compressional stress, other stress state responsible for normal faulting is also identified in few limestones around the Chinpu basin. This stress state is believed to have existed prior to the accretion of the Luzon volcanic arc. The strains measured in the deformed limestones are all less than 4%. The magnitude of strain decreases southward in the Kanghou Limestone but is rather random in the Tungho Limestone. The orientations of the principal strains are generally consistent with those of the principal stresses and reflect a nearly co-axial strain condition.

TI: Discussion on the genetics and the correlation of river terraces in Taiwan
AB: The study on the correlation among eight major river terrace groups was based on the morphological dating method to verify Tomita's correlation scheme (1937). Generally speaking, the Lateritic Terrace (LT) surfaces developed before 30,000 years ago, while the Fluvial Terrace (FT) surfaces have formed within 30,000 B.P.. Tomita's correlation scheme of river terraces may be plausible on the regional scale but not on those in the Chao-chou Fan Terraces, which have younger and low-elevated LT surfaces. The relative height and the presence of lateritic soil on the coverage of river terraces could not have played a major role in the correlation scheme. The time period and the conditions for lateritization in Taiwan remain to be studied. The main factors affecting the development of river terraces also include tectonism, eustatic change and climatic changes. Local tectonic activity plays a principal role in the evolvement of the relative height and the number of levels of river terraces. The dissection of most LT(I) surfaces can be attributed to the decrease in the global sealevel around 30,000 B.P.. As a result, climatic change has caused the formation of the FT surfaces in different regions of Taiwan since the last glacial in spite of drastic eustatic changes. Above all, the complex responses of a river system to tectonism, eustasy and climate have controlled the timing of the formation of river terraces in different regions.

TI: Feasibility study of the thermoluminescence dating method on late Pleistocene coastal sediments southwestern Taiwan
AB: Four Thermoluminscence (TL) ages younger than 50 ka have been determined for the coatal sediments collected from southwestern Taiwan. These TL ages indicate a constant overestimation when compared to the corresponding radiocarbon ages. This is supposedly the result of the sediments not totally being bleached. However, the TL method is still feasible in determining the age of the sediments if the deviation can be eliminated. Based on the experience here, repeated extraction and 80°C 2N HCl treatment are able to center the size fraction and get rid of some clay minerals, thereby really improving the precision of this method. In addition, the samples with low temperature peak dominated were further annealed for 5 minutes at 230°C to enhance the high temperature signal, when the glow curves were read. In other words, the resolution in the high temperature region, used to determine the TL age, can be obviously raised by this modification. Through this modified method, four reasonable TL ages were derived. The linear regression line of An65 is different from the others, that show the exponential regression lines. This is because An65 has a 375° peak (on the basis of a heating rate of 5°C/sec). This implies that the 375°C peak has a high capacity for TL signal accumulation and is appropriate in being applied for older age determination.

TI: Investigation of the Tungshing debris flow hazard in Hualien
AB: During the period of Typhoon Tim, a hazardous debris flow occurred on July 10, 1994 in Tungshing village, Hualien. This debris flow was triggered by heavy rainfall with peak intensity of 104 mm/ hr. Various methods of site investigations, including aerial photograph interpretation, geological and topographic reconnaissance as well as field and laboratory tests, were carried out to obtain the geometric and kinematic characteristics of the debris flow. The aerial photos taken prior and subsequent to the hazard were transformed into large scale topographic maps and were applied for the analysis of topographic changes in gully beds and hill slopes. It was determined that the debris flow emanated from a rockslide near the crest of a hill, moved down a gully channel and later extended and deposited part of the debris material in the village on its way out to sea. The drainage area of the gully was around 80 hectares, and the length of the gully was about 1,400 meters. The average gradient of the gully was about 16°. Grain size distributions of the debris material were determined from field tests, and it was found that the debris consisted of more than 60% fine particles, and thus the debris flow was classified as mudflow. The total decreased volume of the debris material was estimated at approximately 310,000 m3. From the superelevation data obtained from the geomorphological features, the flow velocity and flow rate were estimated to be 9∼10 m/s and 950 m3/s, respectively. The estimated high flow rate and uncommonly long time lag together with the topographic features indicated that the debris flow may have been dammed or plugged one or several times during the flow process.

TI: Leadzinc quartz veins of the Chinmienshan Toucheng northeastern Taiwan
AB: Sulphide quartz veins were discovered unexpectedly during the excavation of a prospective tunnel in the construction of the Taipei-Ilan Expressway. The principal metallic minerals in the veins are galena, sphalerite, wurtzite, pyrite, chalcopyrite and pyrrhotite. Detailed petrographic observations indicate that this lead-zinc vein is closely associated with quartz, calcite and chlorite. Flourite veins are also present. Fluid inclusions in quartz veins demonstrate an evolving H2O-CO2-NaCl-CH4-N2 system. During the experiments, coexisting threephase (aqueous liquid+CO2-liquid+vapor) fluid inclusions with different CO2 contents, homogenized between 310° and 330°C, were trapped during the fluid unmixing of a homogeneous aqueous CO2-bearing hydrothermal fluid. Aqueous two-phase (liquid+vapor) inclusions normally homogenize between 220° and 260°C, which accounts for the successive loss Of CO2, CH4 and N2 during fluid vaporization. This coincides with increasing salinity and decreasing temperatures resulting from high enthalpy steam loss. High angle faults are related to regional strike-slip and extension tectonics. The geotectonic background of this hydrothermal leadzinc quartz veins is very similar to the nearly Chinkuashih gold-copper deposits 25 km north-northeastward. The occurrence of the lead zinc quartz veins is probably related to an underneath deep-seated andesitic and /or granitic igneous body.

TI: Lithofacies analyses of the arcrelated sequence in the Coastal Range eastern Taiwan
AB: Late Cenozoic deposits in the Coastal Range of eastern Taiwan can generally be divided into a lower arc-related sequence and an upper collision-related one. The former, which the present study aims at, can be further subdivided into the Tuluanshan Formation and Kangkou Limestone. These consist of lavas, pyroclastic breccias, tuffs (lapilli tuffs), epiclastic sandstone/conglomerate and limestone. The author reconstructs the lithofacies association and distribution of these deposits in eight sections which exhibit sequential and lateral facies variations in submarine-volcano environments. The sequential facies can be divided in ascending order into lavas, pyroclastic breccias, epiclastics and limestone. The lavas were probably formed under a deep-water environment below the volatile fragmentation depth, whereas the pyroclastic breccias were likely formed above that depth. As the volcanic calderas built up to shallow water above the air-weather wave base, large amounts of epiclastics began to deposit on volcano aprons, and organisms perched around volcano in shallow water. Based on detailed lithological study, lateral lithofacies around the volcanoes can be distinguished into proximal and distal apron facies. The proximal apron facies consists of clast-/matrix-supported pyro-/epiclastics, welded tuff, fallout ash, cross-stratification epiclastics and in-situ limestone. The distal apron facies consists of pillow/sheet lavas, matrix-supported pyroclastic breccias and conglomerates, rhythmic tuffaceous turbidites, slumped beds and carbonate blocks. In general, the pyroclastics show progressively fining and thinning deepward away from the eruption centers. They were deposited in submarine environments, forming a nonchannelized fan-delta system around the volcano aprons.

TI: Mesoscopic structures developed in the Lichi melange during the arccontinent collision in the Taiwan region
AB: In eastern Taiwan, the Lichi Melange forms a chaotic mudstone belt with well-developed scaley foliation. After detailed field investigations on the mesoscopic structures, it is suggested that those structures have developed during the processes of arc-continent underplating and collision between the Eurasian and Philippine Sea plates. The lichi Melange is mainly composed of mudstone with inclusions of sandstone and ophiolitic blocks with varying degrees of fracturing. The mudstone matrix was pervasively sheared resulting in scaly foliation with small slickensided surfaces and striations. The rake of the striations is within the sense of a left-lateral movement. Besides, the sandstone blocks in the foliated matrix are pervasively fractured, and their long axes are generally parallel to the striations of the scaly foliation in the mudstone matrix. The matrix and blocks have apparently suffered from the same stress field. These structures may have occurred collectively in a strong shearing zone during the collision. Three types of fractures, namely, hybrid, extension (crack) and cataclastic shear (web structure) fractures, can be identified in the sandstone blocks. The extension crack in some blocks is well cemented with calcite and is oblique at a high angle to the bedding. These extension fractures are commonly accompanied by normal faulting. In light of the research of deep-sea core, it is suggested that the crack in the sandstone represents an intensive hydrofracture that occurred in the coherent strata beneath or above the shear zone in the accretionary planes in sandstone that are characterized by broken and less than average grain size relative to the surrounding rocks. The web and crack structures commonly observed in sandstone blocks within the melange that exhibit some degree of lithification and healing. The fact that the extension fracture and web structures cross cut by the hybrid fracture and scaly foliation indicates that it formed before the collision. It is suggested that these structures reflect tectonic deformation and stratigraphic disruption during the unerplating process. Thus, based on the mesoscopic structures, the structural styles of the Lichi Melange is best described as a tectonic melange rather than a sedimentary melange or olistostrome.

TI: Mineralogy and geochemistry of granitic rocks from Chinmen Liehyu and Dadan Islands Fujian
AB: The granitic rocks from Chinmen, Liehyu and Dadan, three offshore islands of Fujian, were emplaced in 139.4±0.4 Ma and 100.9± Ma, corresponding to the first and third episodes, respectively, of late Yanshanian magmatism in SE China. These rocks consist predominantly of granite, with subordinate quartz monzonite, granodiorite, trondhjemite and tonalite compositions. Mineralogically, they contain various proportions of quartz, K-feldspar (Or87-97), plagioclase (An11-40), biotite, muscovite and calcic amphibole (ferro-pargasite to ferro=hornblende). Most granitic rocks are peraluminous (A/CNK>1.0 and normative corundum>1%) and display moderately fractionated LREE patterns with negative Eu anomalies, despite the fact that HREE enrichment and LREE depletion are occasionally observed. In the primitive mantle-normalized trace-element diagram, they show a significant Nb depletion similar to those of magmatic rocks from subduction zones. In addition, they plot in the volcanic arc field on the discrimination diagram of Pearce et al. (1984). Overall, these granitic rocks exhibit high-K calc-alkaline to shoshonitic geochemical signatures as commonly observed in I-type granites. However, they usually contain biotites with some compositions similar to A-type granites and are crosscut by abundant late Cretaceous mafic dikes. Combining geologic information from the coastal region of Fujian, late Cretaceous granitic rocks form the offshore islands of Fujian are suggested to represent products from a post-orogenic tectonic environment in the SE China continental margin. Their arc-like geochemical features are interpreted to have been inherited from protoliths formed during previous subduction-related proceses. These rocks are considered genetically different fom the late Cretaceous granitic rocks in east-central Taiwan which likely resulted from a convergent-margin setting.

TI: Pollen anlaysis of middle Last Glacial buried valley sediments in the Shanchia area northern Taiwan
AB: Pollen analysis was carried out with an attempt to understand the late Pleistocene climatic condition of the lower reach of the Tahanhsi River, northern Taiwan. The samples were collected in a buried valley located at Shanchia, where a section of fluvial deposits of 470cm in thickness is exposed due to modern river erosion. According to a previous study, this section was formed between 52ka and 31ka, belonging to the middle Last Glacial period. Our result demonstrates that the herbaceous pollen elements are predominant, especially of Cyperaceae and Gramineae. based on dominant percentage, four pollen zones, ie THa, THb, THc and THd, have been distinguished in the younging order. Zone THa is dominated by Gramineae - Cyperaceae - Pinus - Alnus - Cyclobalanopsis/Quercus - Taxodiaceae. It is worthy to note that among the woody elements we found dominant Pinaceae pollen in consistence with the occurrence of the same tree trunk fossils. This implies that the climate was dry and cool at that time. During the time period of Zone THb, the climate was warmer than Zone THa so that its pollen assemblage is characterized by Cyclobalanopsis/Quercus - Gramineae - Cyperaceae - Taxodiaceae - Pinus - Alnus - Castanopsis. Castanopsis here reaches its maximum pollen percentage value in the study section. This means that a little warm period has occurred during the middle Last Glacial period. Zone THc was formed in a drier but less warmer climate than Zone THb, represented by a dominant assemblage of Cyperaceae - Gramineae - Cyclobalanopsis/Quercus - Taxodiaceae - Pinus - Alnus - Castanopsis. The youngest zone - THd is dominated by Cyclobalanopsis/Quercus - Cyperaceae - Gramineae - Taxodiaceae - Liquidambar - Castanopsis - Alnus, representing a warmer climate than in Zone THc but was less warmer than in Zone THb. Based on our analysis, sthe herbaceous elements were important around the lowland area of northern Taiwan during the middle Last Glacial period. As a conclusion, in 50ka the study area was in a dry and cool climate condition. An intermediate interstadial stage occurred around 37ka, and thereafter the climate turned to a dry condition but with occasional rush rain.

TI: Preliminary study on the late quaternary climatic environment of the Taipei Basin and its possible relation to basin sediments
AB: Deposition in the Taipei Basin was primarily determined by paleoclimate and neotectonic activity. The palynological study of three long cores in the western part of the Taipei Basin shows the occurrence of at least 3 warm-cold climatic cycles (PwIII-PcIII); PwII-PcII and PwI-PcI) since the middle Pleistocene and the overlying Holocene deposits. In the earliest Cycle III (PwIII-PcIII), the studied area of the Taipei Basin was a lake under warm, humid climatic conditions (PwIII), as indicated by the pollen assemblage with a high frequency of Castanopsis and spores. Follwing this, laminated lake sediments with a subalpine forest in PcIII probably represents the coldest climate during the deposition of the Taipei Basin. In climatic Cycle II (PwII-PcII), the earlier warm-dry climate (PwII) is recognizable by the high frequency of Castanopsis accompanied by some elements associated with drought such as Pinus and herbs. Marine incursion occurred in part of the basin at least, as indicated by the low diversity of benthic foraminifers in the Panchiao Core. The later cold-dry climate of Cycle II (PcII) is characterized by herb-dominant assemblages in the fluvial-lake deposits. The warm climate (PwI) of Cycle I correlates with the last interglacial and is distinguished by periods of high temperature and heavy precipitation alternating with less warm and less wet interludes. The last glaciation (PcI) is relatively less cold and less drier compared with previous glacials, except for the dry phase of the LGM. If the three cycles represents the main interglacial-glacial cycles since middle Pleistocene, the earliest age of the basin sediments would be in between 0.3 to 0.4 Ma. The interstadial moist of the last glacial stage might be related to the deposition of thick, large-sized conglomerates in the basin. The Holocene (Hw) is manifested by the relatively higher percentage of Castanopsis. The earliest Holocene has organic-rich layers suggestive of a relatively warm, wet climate. Holocene transgression is clearly recorded in the estuarine deposits of the sequence.

TI: Sequence stratigraphy of the Middle to Upper Miocene strata northern Taiwan a preliminary study
AB: In order to better understand the sea-level fluctuations of the middle to upper Miocene strata in northern Taiwan, sequence stratigraphic analysis is applied to three stratigraphic sections, namely the North Coast, Chenfu and Chuhuangkeng. The chronostratigraphic framework of these 'wave- and tide-dominated shoreline' siliclastic strata can be established by integrating the available micropalaeontologic data. In these sections, parasequences can be divided into facies successions of 5-20m thick. Each parasequence is bounded by marine flooding surfaces which are characterized by intensive bioturbation, shelly lags, or erosion surfaces. Sequence boundaries can be identified by the sharp-based, shoreface sandstones overlying offshore interbeds, and by the top of upward-shoaling facies successions from 'subtidal sandstones' to 'intertidal interbeds' which are associated with mud cracks, rootlets or paleosols. These features represent the abrupt basinward shifting in facies characteristics and unconformities which display the large-scale falls of relative sealevel. Ten, eight and 10 sequences are divided by sequence boundaries in the three studied sections respectively. Three sequence types are recognized by different facies succession. In shelf or coastal sequences, parasequences can be stacked in the aggradational-progradation, retrogradation and progradation successions which represnt lowstand, transgressive and highstand systems tracts, respectively. A complete, large-scale transgression-regression cycle of relative sea-level is displayed by the sequence boundary and systems tracts in each sequence. However, the parasequences in the coastal sequences, which directly overlie shelf deposits, can only be stacked in the aggradation and progradation succession which represent transgressive and highstand systems tracts. An incomplete, large-scale transgression-regression cycle of relative sea-level is implied by the missing of lowstand systems tracts. Constrained by the chronostratigraphic framework, the sequences of three sections appear to be mutually consistent. The sequence stratigraphy of the middle to upper Miocene is established and provides a new scheme of nine correlatable units. Furthermore, the derived relative sea-level changes of the studied sections fluctuate with the 3rd-order eustatic curves on the Vail's chart with only two discrepancies around 15.5 and 13.8 Ma. Consequently, it is inferred that sedimentation of the middle to upper Miocene was dominated by eustacy in northern Taiwan.

TI: Structural evolution in the Hsüehshan range Taiwan
AB: Contraction, transcurrent faulting, block rotation and even extension are four essential tectonic mechanisms involved in the progressive deformation of arcuate collision belts. The neotectonic evolution of the Taiwan Mountain Belt is mainly controlled by the oblique convergence between the Eurasian plate and the Philippine Sea plate as well as the corner shape of the plate boundary. Based on field observations and tectonic analysis, and taking geophysical data and experimental modelling into account, the authors interpret the curved belt of the Hsüehshan Range in terms of contractional deformation (with compression, thrust-sheet stacking, folding, back-thrusting and transcurrent faulting) combined with increasing block rotation, bookshelf-type strike-slip faulting and extension. As a consequence, the formation of the Hsüehshan Range, the division of conjugate strike-slip faulted domains and the variable nature and distribution of paleostresses should not be interpreted in terms of distinct Plio-Quaternary episodes but rather should reflect a single, albeit complicated, regional pattern of deformation. Pop-up structures are widely distributed within the Hsüehshan Range. Because of the high uplift and erosion rate, these pop-up structures can be studied in detail using geometrical, kinematic, and paleostress analyses. This paper attempts to describe the general characteristics of the pop-up structures and their influence on the structural patterns of the Hsüehshan Range.

TI: Sulfidebearing quartz veins in the Szeleng sandstone Chinmienshan northeastern Taiwan a preliminary study on fluid inclusions and stable isotopes

Types I to IV fluid inclusions contain variable amounts of H2,O, CO2 and dissolved salts and may be genetically related to the fluids responsible for the sulfide formation. Variable CO2 content, as well as the correlations between total homogenization temperature and salinity/CO2 content of these fluids inclusions (except those Type III inclusions with total homogenization temperature lower than 210°C) suggest that the responsible fluids could be cogenetic through fluid boiling (fluid immiscibility). On the other hand, the lack of unambiguous prove for the coexistence of fluid-rich and vapor-rich inclusions with appropriate compositions and similar total homogenization temperatures also suggests that the fluids may have different origins. Type V inclusions are empty due to decrepitation, which may have resulted from decompression/heating during sulfide formation. The highest formation temperature of these sulfides would not have been lower than 300°C and the highest pressure, not lower than 0.43 kbar. Thesse sulfides are most probably genetically related to a concealed igneous intrusion. Their sulfur isotopic compositions range from +3.2 to +6.9‰, implying that either these sulfides have multipe sulfur sources or some reactions have effectively fractionated heavy sulfur during igneous evolution and/or sulfide formation. δ18O values of quartz and calcite indicate that the oxygen isotopic compositions of the responsible fluids were mainly buffered by the rocks. TI: The fractures and paleostress of deformed pebbles in the conglomerates of the Toukoshan formation ChiayiYunlin area
AB: Field observations show that the Toukoshan Formation in the Chiayi-Yunlin area has been deformed becoming an open, gentle fold. It is recognized that (1) the degree of cementation, (2) degree of clastic support, and (3) the locations of structural position represent three important factors in controlling the deformation of the pebbles of the conglomerates. Most pebbles with these fractures are found in areas adjacent to faults and in places where conglomerates are more clastic-supported and poorly cemented. Extension fractures and contact marks are frequently observed in places farther away from faults, whereas shear fractures are dominant only in outcrops adjacent to faults. The direction of the maximum principal stress σ1 inferred from extension fractures in deformed pebbles is nearly horizontal and trends 100° to 145° in azimuth. The σ3 trends NE-SW, and its plunge varies from horizontal to vertical. This indicates that the magnitudes of σ2 and σ3 are close to each other, and that they may be interchangeable.

TI: The mechanism of shallow landslides on the argillaceous rock slopes
AB: Shallow landslides are one of the most common types of mass movement that widely occur on argillaceous rock slopes. The thickness of the removed body generally ranges from a few centimeters to less than one meter. Those larger than one meter are very rare. The results of such frequent mass movements include the significant loss of human property, destruction of communications and the reduction of agricultural land. Some parts of Taiwan and the Barbados stand as typical examples of sites which have significantly suffered from frequent shallow landslides. To solve this problem, it was necessary to examine the failure mechanism of these to determine whether a possible solution could be found. The pervasive scaly fabric with polished surfaces and random orientations is the most distinctive characteristic of this kind of argillaceous rock, known as scaly clay. The formation of the scaly texture is usually associated with a high level of stress during its compacting history. It has been found that these scaly fabrics play a very important role in controlling the mechanical behaviour of the scaly clay. The present study employed state-of-the-art laboratory procedures to characterize the physical properties of the studied material. The mechanical behaviour was investigated using standard consolidated-undrained triaxial tests. The results of the experimental study reveal that the scaly texture is the essential part of the failure mechanism. The fabric changed as the material approached the ground surface which was a result of the combination of weathering and surface erosion. The resulting landscape is the widespread, unvegitated, steeply sloped terrain which forms such famous badlands.

TI: 40Ar39Ar dating of mylonitization in the Tananao Schist eastern Taiwan
AB: This paper presents for the first time a successful 40Ar/39Ar dating study of a mylonite zone in a gneiss body in the Tananao Schist near the Hoping area, eastern Taiwan. The mylonite zone, resulting from ductile deformation related to the mountain building in Taiwan, is about 6 meters wide and consists abundantly of fine-grained biotites. Biotite separates from nine samples of the sheared gneiss body yield well-defined plateau dates ranging from 4.1 to 3.0 Ma. Whereas petrographic and microstructural observations reveal that grain size of the biotites decreases as degree of the ductile deformation increases, no apparent co-variation exists between the age data and the above two parameters. Therefore, the biotite dates represent neither the cooling nor resetting ages of the gneiss body, and are considered to indicate the timing of the mylonitization which lasted for over 1 m.y.. Thus, the hinterland of the Taiwan Mountain Belt might have experienced an extensive internal deformation during 4.1-3.0 Ma, and hence has been unlikely a rigid body throughout the mountain building processes. These age data enable us to better constrain the nature and timing of the kinematic evolution of the Taiwan Mountain Belt created by the arc-continent collision.

TI: An experimental petrological study at atmospheric pressure of a basalt from the Sanshia area Taipei county
AB: A basalt sample from Sanshia, Taipei County, was studied with a high temperature furnace at atmospheric pressure. The purposes of this study are to investigate the melting properties of the basaltic magma; to study the crystallization sequence of the phenocrysts; and to estimate the differentiation trend of the magma. The basalt was collected at Charnsoushan of the Sanshia area, Taipei County. It is blackish-gray, fine grained and vesicular. Phenocrysts include olivine, plagioclase, and augite. The rock powder was loaded into a platinum envelope and suspended in a 1-atm vertical-quenching furnace for heating in the air. It was quenched into water after each run. The experimental temperature ranged from 1320°C to 1059°C with the duration time from five to thirty-nine hours. Run products were made as polished sections. Phases were first identified with reflected-light microscopy. Compositions of glasses were analyzed with an electron microprobe. Experimental results showed that the liquidus temperature of the basaltic magma was located at 1274°C and the solidus temperature was estimated to be close to 1059°C. The melting interval is about 215°C. The liquidus minerals are iron-titanium oxides. The following phases to crystallize are plagioclase at about 1187°C; clinopyroxene and orthopyroxene at about 1168°C. The evolution of the basaltic magma shows that the chemical trends are as follows: enrichment in SiO2 and K2O; depletion in total FeO; little variation in the early and middle stage and decrease in the late stage for MgO and CaO; little increase in the early stage and decrease for Al2O3. The fractional crystallization at low pressure is not a main mechanism for the magmatic evolution of the Sanshia basaltic magma.

TI: Biomarkers in the peat deposit of the Toushe Basin central Taiwan
AB: Peat samples from the Toushe Basin have been analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC-MS) for biomarkers. The analysis shows presence of n-alkanes, diterpanes, triterpanes and their unsaturated counterparts. The n-C22--n-C35 alkane series, with a predominance of C27, C29 and C31, is ubiquitous in all samples, suggesting that the peat is mainly composed of organic matter of terrestrial higher plants. Presence of n-C17 and n-C19 alkanes in the samples at depths of 10-13, 18-20 and 27-37m indicates contribution from phytoplankton or algae to the samples, and may therefore imply an aqueous depositional environment. Occurrence of tetracyclic triterpenoids and diterpenoids indicates contribution of terrestrial higher plants of angiosperms and gymnosperms, respectively. Tetracyclic triterpanes are much more dominant than diterpenoids, suggesting that angiosperms are the major source of organic matters for the peat. Presence of Podocarpaceae family of gymnosperms is confirmed based on the ubiquity and dominance of isopimarane and phyllocladane in the samples. Both tetracyclic triterpenoid and diterpenoid distributions show variations with depth, indicating a vegetational change of angiosperms and gymnosperms. The biomarker distributions, eg occurrence of 17β(H), 21β(H) hopanes, C31 22R homohopane, and unsaturated tetracyclic and pentacyclic triterpenes, further indicate that the Toushe peat is still in an early diagenetic stage.

TI: Evolution of the Southern Longitudinal Trough in the incipient Taiwan arccontinent collision zone and its tectonic implication
AB: The Southern Longitudinal Trough (SLT) is a N-S trending elongated trough located just east of the Hengchun in the incipient arc-continent collision zone of offshore southern Taiwan. Detailed seismic sequence analyses and structural interpretation of seismic reflection profiles reveal that the development of SLT probably involved the following three phases: (1) initial formation of a local depression or pull-apart basin on a structural high of a backthrust wedge; (2) the transformation of the local depression into a N-S trending elongated basin as two parallel marginal faults of the basin drew near; and (3) clockwise rotation of the depocenter axes as the Luzon Arc made the same rotation. Three possibilities are suggested for the initiation of the trough: (1) a pull-apart basin bounded by two juxtaposing strike-slip faults; (2) a horsetail-splay structure developed at the southern end of the Longitudinal Valley Fault; and (3) a basin formed due to collapse of a frontal backthrust wedge. Based on the sequential development of SLT, structural patterns and paleomagnetic data, an evolutionary model is proposed to illustrate how the N-S trending accretionary wedge-forearc basin-volcanic arc system evolves into the NNE trending en echelon structural configuration of the onland Coastal Range. After the initial formation of SLT between the two marginal faults, the Luzon Arc rotated clockwise as they moved into the incipient collision zone. The Longitudinal Valley Fault then extended offshore along the western margin of SLT. In future, if the arc-continent collision proceeds, most of the present SLT would be converted into another Longitudinal Valley bounded by two high-angle thrusts, and the rotated Luzon Arc with the NE segmented blocks and the Taitung Trough would become a new Coastal Range with en echelon structures.

TI: Geodynamic implications of presentday kinematics in the southern Ryukyus
AB: Both newly acquired GPS and structural data in the southern Ryukyu subduction zone allowed us to point out some first-order geodynamic implications of the present-day kinematics. Off Hualien, the Hoping Basin lies on a wide zone undergoing north-south transform motion and associated extension between NE Taiwan and the Yonaguni Island. Indeed, this westernmost segment of the Ryukyu Arc, which includes the Yonaguni Island, is moving southward 1.4 cm/yr faster than NE Taiwan with respect to South China. The basin could thus have developped as a pull-apart basin controlled by en-echelon N-S-trending right-lateral strike-slip faults and associated N40°E-trending normal faults during the last 2 m.y., based on present divergence rate. A N50°W-striking valley cutting the southern Ryukyu Arc slope between Yonaguni and Hateruma Islands is explained as a graben caused by the still ongoing differential motion between Yonaguni and Hateruma Ryukyu Arc segments, during the last 400,000 years. If we extrapolate back the present-day kinematics, about half of the southernmost Okinawa Trough might have been formed during the last 2 m.y. The convergence rate between the southern Ryukyu Arc and the Philippine Sea Plate has been estimated to be about 10.5 cm/yr in a direction of N312°east of 123°30'E, and N325°west of 123°30'E. The convergence obliquity is thus estimated to be about 40°and 53°, with respect to the N275°striking Ryukyu Trench, west and east of 123°30'E, respectively. The convergence obliquity increases to 60°west of 122°40'E, because of the northward turn of the trench close to Taiwan. The Ryukyu accretionary wedge (Yaeyama Ridge) can undergo about 3 to 5 cm/yr of transcurrent motion toward Taiwan assuming a mean degree of partitioning of 0.5.

TI: Magnetic analysis on lacustrine deposits of YuanYang Lake northern Taiwan
AB: This study presents the results about the magnetic properties of two lacustrine sediment cores (£YYL2 and £YYL6) sampled from Yuan-Yang Lake in northern Taiwan and discusses their environmental implications. More than 300 specimens from these two cores were analyzed. Results of 14C dating indicate that the calibrated age at the bottom of the core £YYL2 is about 4000 cal.B.P. and that of the core £YYL6 is about 4500 cal.B.P. Both of them seem quite reasonable when we compare the paleomagnetic secular variation patterns of the studied cores with those of marine and lake sediments from Japan compiled by Hyodo et al (1993). They further enable us to estimate the sedimentation rate of Yuan-Yang Lake as about 1 mm/yr. Different variation patterns of magnetic susceptibility of the two studied cores have been found. Core £YYL2 ashows relatively higher value than that of core £YYL6. This phenomenon is thought to be mainly due to the geographic conditions of the coring sites and to the magnetic mineral contained. Site £YYL6 is located closer to the lake flank but farther away from the source of clastic sediments than site £YYL2. Furthermore, the former is in a shallower water depth with weaker inflow force than the latter. With less clastic debris and more organic materials, therefore, core £YYL6 naturally has weaker magnetic susceptibility signals. Actually, samples with more organic materials are apt to be dominated by ilmenite instead of magnetite as their major magnetic carrier. Several high peaks of magnetic susceptibility appear in the layers of core £YYL2 dominated by green-gray sediments instead of organic materials. It is related to the fact that these layers contain much more magnetic minerals. Most of the sediments of these layers are considered to come from surrounding rock formations during dry periods. Assuming a constant sedimentation rate of about 1 mm/yr in the studied area, four major dry periods are found at about 3300, 2800, 2000 and 800 yr B.P. In addition, frequency-dependent low field magnetic susceptibility analysis indiactes that it is generally very low for core £YYL2, suggesting that it is devoid of very fine-grain magnetic minerals.

TI: Management and remedial measures of a dipslope excavationa case study
AB: More attention has been paid on dip-slope cutting and engineering after the recent Lincoln County hazard in the hilly suburb of Taipei City, Taiwan. This paper presents a case history of design, construction and remedial measures of a near-vertical 13.8m open-cut slope at Nei-Hu district of northeastern Taipei City. The bedrock of the job site is sandstone and shale interbeds of the Miocene Shihti Formation, which has a dip-slope at the northern side of the site. Some passive retaining structures including micropiles, rock bolts and shotcretes were originally designed to protect the open-cut face during excavation instead of heavy retaining ones. Instruments including inclinometers, rebar strain gauges etc. were installed for the monitoring purpose and back analysis. At the last two stages of excavation, weathered clay seams between the interbeds were unexpectedly exposed and the rock slope slid before ample insertion of rock bolts. An emergency action was taken to prevent further movement of the slope, and reassessment was made to remedy the nearly failed cut slope. The paper also describes some details of feedback analysis of rock bolts and wedge blocks.

TI: Meteoric diagenesis and stable isotopic compositions of the Hengchun limestone southern Taiwan
AB: The Pleistocene Hengchun Limestone of the Kueitzechiao-Oluanpi area was deposited during the Quaternary eustatic sea-level fluctuations and the ongoing Penglai Orogeny. Previous studies have established a N-S facies-geometry profile and proposed a depositional history of the Limestone. The Hengchun Limestone in the Kueitzechiao-Oluanpi area was interpreted to have developed during two major glacioeustatic sea-level cycles. It was suggested that the limestone on the Oluanpi terrace, in particular, developed during the younger cycle. To study subsurface lithofacies and diagenesis of the Hengchun Limestone, three boreholes were drilled on the Oluanpi terrace. Petrographic and stable isotopic studies of the core samples have identified: 1) predominant meteoroic diagenesis texture, 2) strong meteoric influences on stable carbon and oxygen isotopic compositions, and 3) two subaerial exposure surfaces that define three depositional cycles. The results are consistent with the glacioeustatic interpretation for the origin of the Hengchun Limestone. The present study, however, further reveals that the Limestone of the Oluanpi terrace may have formed during three minor glacio-eustatic cycles.

TI: Morphology and origin of the Shoushan submarine canyon off southwestern Taiwan
AB: Detailed morphology and configuration of the Shoushan Canyon on the upper slope off southwest Taiwan are described using newly acquired bathymetric data and seismic profiles. The canyon extends from the upper slope southwestward to a water depth of 1,700 m where it merges into the larger Penghu Canyon to the west. Two tributary canyons enter into the Shoushan Canyon from the west at water depths shallower than 1,500 m. The canyon shows high relief, steep walls (about 8 degrees) and V-shaped cross sections, which are typical in canyon morphology. The canyon floor increases its depth from 394 m to 1,748 m, stretches for a length of about 50 km and has an averaged width of 4.4 km. The Shoushan Canyon not only can be considered a single submarine canyon but also a tributary canyon that joins into the larger Penghu Canyon to the west. Morphologic and seismic characteristics suggest that the canyon may have a composite origin (e.g., controls of erosion and structure). Vigorous submarine down-cutting along the structurally weak zone is considered as the main cause to form the Shoushan Canyon, which is characterized by a relatively straight course on the Kaoping Slope.

TI: Recent geologic structures in the Chipenchushan area southern Taiwan
AB: Chipenchushan is located in the southern part of the Central Range metamorphic belt of Taiwan, which has been uplifted and exhumed since Pliocene due to collision between the Asian continental margin and the Luzon volcanic arc. This particular site is censidered important and crucial for observing recent structures due to the collision because the complicated huge anticlinorium of the Central Range has the general plunge to the south and thus the metamorphic basement has been just unroofed relatively intact. Basically, according to the scale and style of the structures, recent structural activities in this area can be generally divided into three consecutive stages, namely (1) 1st stage: west-verging thrusting and concomitant folding as a consequence of a push from E to W, (2) 2nd stage: east-verging backthrusting and concomitant folding and (3) 3rd stage: mainly folding due to a near N-S compression. These activities and structural phenomena clearly represe-nt the products of an area undergoing general compression, resulted from the oblique arc-continent collision driven by the northwest push of the Philippine Sea plate. The aforementioned structural activities are believed to have taken place at a rather shallow level and at a relatively young age, reflecting quite faithfully different interactions of various stress with geologic material through time. The mountain-building process of this area in total, can be regarded as mainly represented by piling up of the thrust and backthrust sheets, with folding playing a relatively minor and concomitant role. The orogenic model of this area may be comparable to that of the Moine Thrust zone of Scotland described by Knipe (1990).

TI: Scarp evolution of fan terraces along the Lanyang River Taiwan
AU: Sung Q;Tsai H;Fu J;Chyi S;Lee P
AB: An evolutionary model of scarp slopes has been constructed for the Lanyang River area of northeastern Taiwan. In this area, younger terraces have higher free-face height/scarp height ratios than older terraces, while the latter have higher debris-slope height/scarp height ratios than the former. The time necessary for a slope to evolve from the free-face to the debris-slope stage is estimated to be less than 1,000 years for the Mimodan fan and the Fubur fan. When a scarp slope forms, its debris-slope angle initially increases exponentially, and then flattens when the debris slope takes over the entire slope. On the other hands, its free-face angle decreases exponentially and then approaches a constant. The slope evolution observed here is close to the non-parallel retreat model. A general slope evolution model can be applied to terrace scarps of subtropical Taiwan as well as scarps in arid western American, in spite of climatic differences. Vegetation cover and weathering conditions on the scarps, however, may vary because of different climatic conditions. These different conditions can result in different rates of degradation and different repose angles. The angles of repose measured in the Lanyang River area for scarps without free-faces may be as large as 45°in contrast to those ranging from 33°to 38°proposed by previous works. The result may improve the resolution of morphological dating in river terraces.

TI: Studies of earthquake seismology in Taiwan during the 18971996 period
AB: Since 1897, when the first seismometer was installed, a large number of seismographic stations have been constructed and many studies concerning earthquake seismology have been done in the Taiwan region. A brief history of the evolution of seismic networks is described first. Then, the publications concerning earthquake seismology in the region during the 1897-1996 period are reviewed. The important issues in consideration are (1) the crustal and upper-mantle structures (including one-dimensional velocity models, three-dimensional velocity models, Q values, and anisotropy); (2) earthquake quantification; (3) earthquake catalogues; (4) studies of pre-1945 earthquake sequences; (5) studies of post-1945 earthquake sequences; (6) seismicity (including the spatial distributions of earthquakes, temporal variations in earthquakes, remotely triggered seismicity, frequency distributions of earthquakes, b-values, relations between mainshocks and aftershocks, seismic energy, fractal characterization of earthquakes, and seismic code); (7) seismotectonics (including stress patterns and regional seismotectonic models); (8) earthquake prediction research; (9) induced seismicity; and (10) earthquakes and geothermal activities. Comments and judgments on the main results obtained by certain authors for some issues are made. In addition, several future studies are also suggested.

TI: Tectonic implications of an aseismic belt beneath the Eastern Central Range of Taiwan Crustal subduction and exhumation
AB: This study proposes a tectonic model of crustal subduction and exhumation to explain the phenomena of an aseismic belt beneath the Eastern Central Range of Taiwan. The aseismic belt, generally parallel to the strongly convergent boundary between the Eurasian and Philippine Sea plates in Taiwan, is very unusual because it is in sharp contrast to the very seismically active neighboring areas. In order to understand the tectonic implications of this aseismic belt, the author first reviews a variety of geophysical and geological evidence including seismic tomography, fault plane solutions, heat flow, crustal deformation, strain, uplift and erosion rates, geomorphology and results of isotopic studies. The tectonic history in the Taiwan region suggests that the continental margin of the Eurasian plate has been slightly subducted beneath the Philippine Sea plate. The light continental crust of the former was dragged downward by its dense mantle lithosphere. In the meantime the buoyancy forces of the subducted continental crust built up with depth. Eventually, the exhumation occurred when the buoyancy forces increased enough to produce decoupling at the base of the crust and then failure in front of the subduction zone. This model can be used to account for the absence of seismicity beneath the Eastern Central Range due to higher temperature within the exhumed material, which is considered generally consistent with most of the geophysical and geological evidence reviewed in this paper.

TI: The Tapu earthquake of 1993 a study of source parameters using nearsource ground motion
AB: The generalized reflection-transmission coefficient matrix and discrete wavenumber method were used to model the December 15, 1993, Tapu earthquake (M(L)=5.8). To estimate the source parameters, the ground motion at twelve stations located in the range of 5 to 18 km from the epicenter were selected for study. With a circular crack model assumed, this earthquake was moving at a constant velocity along the radical direction. A spatial dependence slip-time function was used to synthesize ground displacement in the near-source distances. The agreement of the observed waveforms and the computed seismograms yielded an average dislocation of 74 cm over the circular fault with a radius of 2.0 km. The seismic moment was estimated to be 2.8 X 1024 dyne-cm, and the rupture velocity was 2.0 km/sec. The average rise time was 0.5 sec, while the stress drop was 153 bars. This stress drop corresponds to a strain drop of about 5 X 10-4.
